questions.question_text: What is the NHRP role in DMVPN? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Obtains the next-hop to be used for routing
choices.B: Routes the packet through the tunnel
choices.E: It requires each tunnel endpoint to have a unique network ID
choices.C: Identifies the PIM-SM RP used to route the packet

discussion.content: IPsec over GRE have no benefits and not very useful. Thus, correct answer is C.

Question is ambiguous. Are we talking about GRE over IPsec, or IPSec over GRE?
Answer C is only correct for GRE over IPsec.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about an IPsec/GRE tunnel?

choices.C: GRE encapsulation occurs before the IPsec encryption process.
choices.B: An IPsec/GRE tunnel must use IPsec tunnel mode.
choices.A: The GRE tunnel source and destination addresses are specified within the IPsec transform set.
choices.D: Crypto map ACL is not needed to match which traffic will be protected.
Add the tunnel subnet to the routing process so that it exchanges routing updates across that interface.
choices.A: Configure a physical interface or create a loopback interface to use as the tunnel endpoint.
choices.E: Add all subnets to the crypto access-list, so that IPsec encrypts the GRE tunnel traffic.
choices.C: Add the tunnel interfaces to the routing process so that it exchanges routing updates across that interface.
choices.F: Add GRE traffic to the crypto access-list, so that IPsec encrypts the GRE tunnel traffic. ABDF

questions.answer_description:
Four steps to configure GRE tunnel over IPsec are:
1. Create a physical or loopback interface to use as the tunnel endpoint. Using a loopback rather than a physical interface adds stability to the configuration.
2. Create the GRE tunnel interfaces.
3. Add the tunnel subnet to the routing process so that it exchanges routing updates across that interface.
4. Add GRE traffic to the crypto access list, so that IPsec encrypts the GRE tunnel traffic.
An example of configuring GRE Tunnel is shown below:
interface Tunnel0
ip address 192.168.16.2 255.255.255.0
tunnel source FastEthernet1/0
tunnel destination 14.38.88.10
tunnel mode gre ip
Note: The last command is enabled by default so we can ignore it in the configuration)
(Reference: CCNP Routing and Switching Quick Reference)
questions.question_text: What are the four main steps in configuring a GRE tunnel over IPsec on Cisco routers? (Choose four.)

discussion.content:
depends on "ospf network type" and not on "interface type"
1) PtP - 10/40/40
2) NBMA - 30/120/120

Why is R2-R3 correct and not R1-R3. From the diagram. Both links appear to be pt-to-pt links, so I believe the timers should be 10,40,40. What's the difference that stands out for pt-to-pt links vs non_broadcast links. Seems really tricky for the network types?????????

questions.answer_description: We can see the configured timers using the following command:

choices.A: The R1-R3 link needs the neighbor command for the adjacency to stay up
choices.D: R3 is responsible for flooding LSUs to all the routers on the network
choices.B: The R2-R3 link OSPF timer values are 30, 120, 120
choices.C: The R1-R3 link OSPF timer values should be 10, 40, 40

discussion.content: The TAC engineer should be fired :D

choices.A: The crypto isakmp configuration is not correct.
choices.B: The crypto map configuration is not correct.
choices.C: The interface tunnel configuration is not correct.
choices.D: The network 172.16.1.0 is not included in the OSPF process

questions.answer_description: The address of the crypto isakmp key should be 192.168.1.2, not 172.16.1.2 -> A is correct.
